required_header.download_date: ClinicalTrials.gov processed this data on November 19, 2021
required_header.link_text: Link to the current ClinicalTrials.gov record.

clinical_study.brief_title: Echogenic Versus Non-echogenic Needles for Venous Access
clinical_study.official_title: Ultrasound Guided Subclavian Vein Cannulation. Echogenic Needles Versus Non-echogenic Needles

brief_summary.textblock: Randomized controlled intervention study comparing echogenic needles with non echogenic needles for ultrasound guided venous access in the subclavian vein.

detailed_description.textblock:
Patients undergoing certain surgical procedures and patients in intensive care unit require a central venous catheter (CVC) for infusion of medicaments and for monitoring. Central venous access (CVA) can be performed both with a blind technique or an ultrasound guided technique. A common place for CVA is the subclavian vein.
While many guidelines recommend the use of ultrasound for jugular access, there are no explicit recommendations for subclavian CVA For ultrasound guided CVA procedures good needle visualization is important to successfully place the needle and catheter in the correct position.
Echogenic needles can give better needle visualization when performing ultrasound guided CVA procedures. Theoretically, the use of echogenic needles should improve performance time and success rates, and reduce complication rates due to a better needling control.
The investigators will investigate the use of echogenic needles for vascular access.
A prospective randomized controlled trial design will be used. Echogenic needles will be compared with non-echogenic (standard) needles. The main null hypothesis states that there is no difference in access time between the needles.

study_design_info.intervention_model_description: Two arms Venous access either with echogenic needles or with non-echogenic needles
study_design_info.masking_description: Participant will be anesthetized and asleep Outcome assessor will not be in the operating theater during the procedure

primary_outcome.measure: Time from skin puncture of the needle until aspiration of venous blood.
primary_outcome.description: Time from skin puncture of the needle until aspiration of venous blood in the syringe. Time till venous access

secondary_outcome.measure: Time from skin puncture until catheter in place
secondary_outcome.description: Time from skin puncture until the catheter in place in the subclavian vein.

secondary_outcome.measure: Success with venous access in first needling attempt
secondary_outcome.description: Success in first attempt is defined as one skin puncture and directly into the subclavian vein

secondary_outcome.measure: Number of needling attempts before venous access
secondary_outcome.description: Number of attempts is defined as the counted number of needle attempts intermitted by a needle withdrawal of at least 0.5 cm until aspiration of venous blood.
Number of skin punctures is defined as the counted number of skin punctures until aspiration of venous blood.
Discontinuation of the procedure or change of site for vascular access

secondary_outcome.measure: Localization of catheter tip in x-ray
secondary_outcome.description: Catheter misplacement judged by x-ray. X-ray will be performed after the surgery and a blinded observer will describe the localization of the catheter.

secondary_outcome.measure: The anaesthetists subjective experience with needle visualization
secondary_outcome.description: After performing the vascular access the anaesthetists are asked about how they found the visualization of the needle using a Numeric Rating Scale

secondary_outcome.measure: The anaesthetists subjective experience with the needle placement
secondary_outcome.description: After performing the vascular access the anaesthetist is asked how the needle placement was using a Numeric Rating Scale

Adverse events, including information of the seriousness, treatment needed, resolution and relevant judgment concerning the causal relationship with the investigational devices or procedure will be summarized for safety information

Adverse device effects, including information of the seriousness, treatment needed, resolution and relevant judgment concerning the causal relationship with the investigational devices or procedure will be summarized

arm_group.description: venous access performed under ultrasound guidance with echogenic needles
venous access performed under ultrasound guidance with non-echogenic needles

intervention.description: echogenic needles for intravenous access (subclavian vein) ultrasound guided procedure

criteria.textblock:
Inclusion Criteria:
undergoing a surgical procedure requiring a CVC Patients must be at least 18 years of age. Patients that have given informed written consent.
-
Exclusion Criteria:
- Patients that do not speak or understand Norwegian language.
- Skin disease or infection affecting the whole-body surface or within the area of examination.
- Patients with untreated coagulopathy
- Known vascular abnormality
- Any reason why, in the opinion of the investigators, the patient should not participate.
- Subject participates in a potentially confounding drug or device trial during the course of the study.

overall_official.affiliation: Department of Anaesthesiology Oslo University Hospital, Oslo, Norway
